Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 10:50AM cbm wrote: pejkug3, I am a lot older than you are (59 now, 57 at diagnosis), but my reasons may be helpful to you.  I wrote them down and recited them to the docs without hesitation.  I wanted a bmx as soon as I was diagnosed. Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2009 05:33PM - edited Oct 23, 2009 03:45AM by cbm Hi Clarice.  I may have a different view, but I think you can manage either way.  On balance, I'd prefer the hotel, but like the other ladies said, that's a risk also.  Most of the risk is in the handling of things--the touching and lack of cleanliness, and you can get that both places.  You can go a long long way toward keeping your site clean with just precautions that you and your sister take.  I was lucky to come right home after surgery.  But I have a dog and a cat and a 90 year old house that never seems clean enough for me.  Nothing is completely sanitary.  You have to do the best you can.  Invest in some disposable gloves and use them.  Ask the hotel to supply clean sheets every day, and change the bed yourself (not you, of course, your sis).  Buy some spray disinfectant, cleaning supplies, and wipies (as my granddaughter calls them) and use them constantly.  Before you get in the bed, spray the disinfectant on the sheets and pillow--you might even buy a new pillow for yourself. I don't want to be graphic, but cleanliness in ALL things is key, so you want to be particularly finicky with respect to the bathroom.  Urinary tract infection from the catheter is common so you have to be especially vigilant and it isn't easy after surgery, I'm sorry to say.  I don't think I'd go home for a few days.  I think you want to be near the source of immediate medical attention until you know the healing has begun to take place and you are past the worst of the risk.  I was lucky to have a helper stay with me in the hospital (I have that Aflac Cancer Insurance and it is amazing) and to have been placed on a special unit because my bp dropped like a rock in the first minutes of surgery (allergy to muscle relaxant).  So I got an extra day and some other benefits.  However, while there I watched the aide clean up around the bed, pick up bandage debris, and then rearrange my cup, juice glass, and straw using the same gloved hand.  My personal nurse simply discarded them--but I'd have been at risk if that kind of thing hadn't been noticed.  Vigilance is  a constant from now on--you have to be militant about what touches you and what you touch. I emptied my own drains, which I had for ten days.  I used gloves and cleaned my sites with alcohol and used triple antibiotic on them.  (I also had a bilateral mastectomy with left side axillary clearance and no reconstruction to date.)  Once you get into the habit of being germ phobic, it helps with everything and this becomes critical during chemo also, because infection is your enemy and can cause you to miss an infusion. (for me that meant one more week without my eyelashes.  Unacceptable.  ) I would say that you could use a few pillows for travel, definitely request a wheelchair and board as a special assistance passenger, and after seven to ten days, you should be fine, although not normal.  One question I'd have for your nurse or physical therapist is whether or not to bandage your arm where you had nodes removed for the flight. (lymhedema)  Be careful with your pain management if you are mobile, as you might be more likely to stumble and fall.  I was not allowed to use the stairs in my house without help if I was taking pain meds.  DH made me promise. You are one brave lady Clarice.  I admire your courage and determination, and your independence.  Your daughter is getting a heck of a great example of strength and commitment.  Wow. I hope it goes well.  Pain was not much of an issue for me; I was mostly numb (not psych-wise, nerve-ending-wise) which makes it all easier.  Find a pt wherever you are or learn to massage your arms and incision areas so the scar tissue doesn't adhere--you want to keep the fascia supple ( I think I said that right). Warmly Cathy

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2010 08:54AM - edited Aug 14, 2010 09:09AM by cbm Hello, allenroc.  I was stage 2a and had gone through bilateral mx, but delayed reconstruction.  I was postmenopausal at diagnosis (age 56) and had not had a particularly unpleasant menopause.  I was 90% er/pr and Her2+.  I took birth control pills during perimenopause, and I imagine that contributed to my breast cancer--or maybe it kept it at bay for a while, who knows. I am a DES daughter and had a bicornate uterus, which supported a decision to do the hysterectomy along with the oopherectomy that my hormone status suggested offered the best offense against recurrence.    In fact, I was told that I had been at high risk for ovarian and endometrial cancers and had not known that.  So I had DaVinci ooph and then internal hysterctomy.  I was already on antihormonals--Arimidex at the time, now Femara, which I prefer.   Both procedures were, for me, a piece of cake--I was driving within a few days and never had pain that had to be controlled, so Advil was it.  I had no bladder or bowel problems, I seem to have almost no scars, not that it matters.  I will say that the dryness and atrophy is very inconvenient to control but if you manage expectations, and go to the necessary trouble, you will benefit. . . I would not do HRT; with ER/PR + you should be going the other direction, unless there's something I'm missing.   Hot flashes are manageable, although they sure aren't fun.  I live in Florida, so summers are, well, hot.  I happen to take Inderal for a cardiac arrhythmia and I believe it cuts down on the worst symptoms of menopause, but that would be a way-off-label use.   I have heard that the anti-depressants can help also, as can vitamins and good diet.  My hot flashes aren't distracting to me anymore.  I hope this helps.  I would not do any of what has been suggested to you without a second opinion and a thorough discussion with an oncologist.  I highly recommend DaVinci but only if done with a surgeon experienced in DaVinci.  The hysterectomy part. . . well, I don't know what the risk reduction is for you.  If it's a lot, it might be worth it.   Warmly, Cathy  ps. . . sorry. . . meant to tell you that DaVinci is something that hospitals that have it tend to advertise.  So you can call the hospital and ask if they have it and who are the surgeons trained to use.  And, I had the "thickened walls" and some big fibroid cysts but no cancer.  They did not do the pathology until I was out of surgery; my path report on the ooph/hyst was as complete as my breast surgery report was--they looked through every single piece of tissue that was removed.  My research process consisted of asking my oncologist to direct me to the right surgeon for me, and my asking his p.a. if she agreed, which she did.  The surgeon, a specialist in women's cancers, told me that a.) Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2009 10:42PM - edited Oct 23, 2009 09:20PM by cbm Hello Anne; my sister had endometrial cancer.  She was about 53/54 at the time of diagnosis and she had only been taking hrt for a short while when she developed symptoms.  When they did her surgery, they found two primary tumors--one from the HRT and one apparently the result of HNPCC.  Or not;they really don't know.  They treated her with surgery and rads, and no more hrt.  One tumor had hormone receptors, the other did not.  One was grade 1, the other a 2. Her HNPCC (also known as Lynch Syndrome) was the form in which the repair gene is missing.  One year later I was diagnosed with breast cancer, a mixed tumor with ILC, IDC, and DCIS all hidden within a fibroadenoma.  There have been some small studies that show that Lynch is a probable culprit in bc, also.  My brother has had kidney cancer.  Dad had prostate.  Mom bc.  Everyone else succumbed to cardiac incidents, or lived to a ridiculous age. Anyway.  I had both ooph and hysterectomy in March and I was postmenopausal and already on Armidex.  I had the DaVinci type surgery and was fine in about 72 hours, but the cumulative effects of the bilat surgery, chemo in 08, then Arimdex and the ooph/hyst made me a little ditzy for a while. I didn't have any symptoms other than increased comfort--they removed a lot of fibroids.  One thing you need to remember with Lynch you are also at risk for other cancers--colon, stomach, bowel, melanoma.  So you have to have more frequent oscopies.  I did not have the gene test becasue my family's varient is a missing gene and my insurance wouldn't pay for the $3K test.  My docs assume the syndrome and we go from there. Our mom took DES also, which was known to cause cervical cancer in young women but we don't know what else in our generation of women.  My belief is that it just fueled an already vulnerable cluster of genetic conditions and that was that.  My sister was told there is no systemic treatment and they removed everything.  One tumor was near the lymph channel and that prompted a more aggressive surgical and radiation course. I hope this helps you.  Warmest regards, Cathy

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 01:08PM cbm wrote: Polyana--I gather from your earlier posts that you aren't in the U.S. so I'm not sure if I can answer any of your questions about treatment.  Your path report and mine are similar--I was Grade 2, Stage 2a, Er 90%+ Pr 90%+ but I was HEr2 + also.  I had a smaller tumor with a large lymph node and had a bilateral mx followed by dose dense ACTx4 and THx12, followed by 2 years of herceptin and no radiation.  I love my port, which is higher than usual in my chest because of the mx.  I was diagnosed in 2008 and was finished with everything but herceptin and reconstruction within about 8 months.   I had a pet scan that confirmed one node and nothing else.  I did not have any blood supply or vascular invasion noted near my tumor.  Your her2 status is negative, which is a sign that your cancer is not as accelerated as mine was.  Her2 makes the cancer grow faster and means you need additional treatment, herceptin. There is good reason to shrink the tumor before surgery; they can see if and how the chemo is working.  Lots of women have this form of treatment.  You may never know the real stage if you do that; there is no reason to be put off by that.   The length of each chemo session depends on which chemo you get, and whether you get a dose dense form.  Usually you get a lot of tests before chemo, to check you heart function and that sort of thing.  I got an orientation on the day my chemo started.  If you get premeds, you shouldn't plan to drive, and nearly everyone gets premeds, which are given to help you tolerate the drugs and the process.  The premeds given in the U.S. include benadryl, Zantac, decadron, and lots of other things to make the day and night tolerable.  I went to chemo in a sizable clinic and was attended by the nicest most competent nurses on earth; there was always a doctor in the clinic who could check on anything from a slight fever to an ingrown toenail starting to look infected.  They gave me lost of info about nutrition and self-care.  It's critical to stay hydrated and healthy. Regarding stage, I'm a believer that the more treatment the better, so although I was stage 2, I'd have been more than happy to get the treatment equivalent of stage 3.  Even though we root for the lower stage results, stage estimation and treatment calibration are not that precise.   Best wishes for a smooth road ahead, that leads you back to health.  Perhaps some of the women who are starting neoadjuvant  (chemo before surgery) chemo can help with info about their protocols and the reasons for them.   Warmest, Cathy

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 08:06PM cbm wrote: Hi, Ling; I wanted to offer some thoughts regarding your other question, about starting work.  I don't know much about IBC or the kind of experience you are having with your diagnosis, but with respect to your new job, you do need a plan.  First, you ought to get an attorney to look at your contract and give you an opinion on the agreement and what you have to do to protect your interests.  Even if you are otherwise protected, the contract may have protections for either you or the employer that you should know about before you tell them anything.  Second, once your doctors have more information and they tell you what your options are, decide whether (or when) you want to begin work.  Under US laws, you can ask for reasonable accommodation for your needs and your treatments, and it is likely that your employer will provide what you need.  California is particularly employee-friendly.  The important thing is to be as specific as you can be, and express your best intentions.  Your attorney can tell you more about what you qualify for and how to access it properly.  I'm not suggesting an adversarial stance, but an informative briefing that will help acclimate you to how employment law works in California and the US. Every state is different. Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 04:47PM - edited Apr 19, 2010 04:50PM by cbm Hello, lizziemack; I had a bilateral mx in 2008, never considered alternatives and have never regretted it:  1.  I was large breasted and figured I would never get them to match, not that they did in the first place. 2.  They were somewhat deceitful in that my tumor hid out through three or more mammos, 6 clinical exams, and countless self-exams.  If one could hide it, so could the other. 3.  I had an ILC component and it likes to come back in the other breast. 4.  I was 56, not up for lots of time spent in surgery or pain in the interest of the best possible effect. 5.  I like to limit my exposure to radiation, and lumpectomy would have required it.  A single mastectomy was not on my radar.  I could not fathom nearly a year of treatment with one breast and a similarly sized prosthesis.  I wasn't even sure if I could get such a prosthesis.  And I could only imagine the back problems from the uneven weight distribution. 6.  I really like symmetry and it seemed more manageable to have nothing there and then decide what exactly I wanted later. 7.  I had a timeline for how long I was willing to devote to all of this, and the bilateral mx gave me the fastest return to activity.  I was in chemo three weeks after surgery, to the day. That meant I was done faster and got my hair back sooner.   8.  I wanted to know going in what I would have coming out of the surgery.  I wasn't convinced there wasn't more lurking in there, so if I went in thinking golfball I knew I could come out minus baseball and I didn't want that uncertainty on top of all the other uncertainty.  9.  I figured if I got through all of it okay, then I would have time and the patience to find the right reconstruction surgery for me.  Before the surgery I was getting all kinds of conservative consults.  More recently I was offered the full range of options.  DIEP would be tempting if I were your age.  It comes with a tummy tuck that I'd rather have than the breasts.   10.  It was easy for me.  It isn't for everyone; before I was diagnosed I had seen and spoken with so many friends and in my mind I was always forming a clear idea of what I'd do if it were me.  When it finally was me, it was just a step forward.  My oncologist was not all that supportive; my surgeon was not thrilled and made me go get a plastics consult.  After the surgery he told me that having seen my tumor in it's little hiding place he had to agree that I'd done the right thing for me. Once I make a decision I don't look back, so I have no regrets.  Even though I'm in the Florida heat all the time, I've been able to dress around my figure, though I'm not a skinny girl, more like a size 12.  My clothes finally fit.   You really do have to do what is right for you, but for me that meant establishing my priorities, my resources, my got-to-haves, and my don't cares.  I had an amazing p.a. who had run a huge breast center and gave me confidence when she said there is no right or wrong on this one.  Do whatever you want. Warmest thoughts and gentle hugs, Cathy

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 08:31AM cbm wrote: Hi, Lifeisbeautiful.  I think that part about your hair sounds like great fun and I wish I'd done it. I think medullary is a specific phenotype; one with a slightly better prognosis than some other forms.  Remember the info that you have is all pretty preliminary, but a Grade 2 in a woman your age would be a very good thing, becasue young women often get more aggressive (Grade 3) forms. Tumor cells have three characteristics that are scored from one to three, that when added up create the Scharf Bloom Richardson score.  "One" is the best, the least "different" from normal cells, and the "three" is the worst, or most different.  The scores represent tubule formation, pleomorphism or degree of change, and mitosis, or speed of reproduction.  The highest SBR score is a 9, the lowest is a 3.  A 3,4,5 means a Grade 1, 6 and 7 mean a Grade 2, and 8 and 9 are an SBR 3. Take the percents with a grain of salt--once you know your estrogen receptors and Her2 status you might well get an even better percent.  Lymph node involvement is another variable.   I know what you mean about deing distracted by the numbers and percents--I was begging to find a way into the nineties.  Deep sigh.  They are just numbers, and you don't have all the info yet. Most chemotherapy does cause you to lose your hair, but some forms when combined with a cold cap can be less damaging.  You won't know what you are going to get for sure until after your final pathology, which is after surgery.  Two centimeters is not huge.  Warmest hugs; be brave.  It sounds like you are in good hands.  You should get a copy of all your reports and start to keep them all together.  And take notes; you always think of stuff later. Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 12:48PM - edited Oct 23, 2009 06:46AM by cbm Hello, Ann.  My MRI showed a second area in the same breast as my primary tumor and I asked for an ultrasound first, which was inconclusive.  They told me I'd have to have a second core biopsy (MRI or US guided) and I said no, I'm having a mastectomy.  I could see the future unfolding. . . one biopsy at a time.  Make them go away. When they did my bilat mx, the second area was nothing.  They did however find a fair amount of DCIS, and my surgeon who had been pushing for lumpectomy instead of mastectomy admitted I'd done the right thing for me. I hear your objective loud and clear--save the breast.  I think that's why the difference.  You are getting the tests that it takes in order to do that.  It's not unreasonable, and you are apparently in prudent and caring hands.  I don't think cancer moves that fast--another test is not going to delay you longer than is safe or they would tell you that and insist you consider other options. Warmest, you are not too far off the optimum schedule and you are right on schedule for your needs. Cathy

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 03:08AM - edited Nov 13, 2009 03:11AM by cbm Hi, Ann.  My oncologist told me I didn't need radiation, so I guess he's the one who'd have said so if I did.  And I was opposed to radiation, so I was okay with that. Fast forward to the present.  I wish I'd had more of a debate over it.  I had one big lymph node, and those with one to three nodes who elect mx usually didn't used to get rads; lumpectomy with any nodes did.  Now, there is some thought (esp. among rads oncologists) that this hair splitting might be arbitrary. I know you had no nodes, and I don't mean to trigger a suggestion you didn't ask for.  But if it were me, I might ask for a consult just to see what the radiation oncologist might say he or she could do for me, and not do to me, and how, when and why.  You don't have to do anything with the info.  And your oncologist might benefit from the dialogue. You can get a lot of info on PubMed doing a search on mastectomy, radiation, nodes and a few other terms.  Nodes and margins are definitely two different things but I suspect your instincts are to make sure the discussion doesn't get lost. Warmest, Cathy

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 06:30PM - edited Oct 23, 2009 04:59AM by cbm Hi, Ann.  What a mess.  But I think your instincts are good--the sooner the better.  You need to get through this and into the chemo phase. If I were you I wouldn't start over.  I believe I'd nail the date that's only two weeks away, then get in to see the oncologist and ask him or his p.a. to intervene and make it happen sooner, on the basis that you need to get into chemo.  He will know that the tumor has grown and he can part the waters if need be. Alternatively, and I know you won't like this so I shouldn't even say it, you could just do the mastectomy now and have the reconstruction phase later.  Sorry, I know that is the last thing you want and I agree none of this should have happened.  But it is an option that might speed things up.  I didn't go to a big cancer center either.  The cancer center in my region was slower than my private arrangements that were coordinated by the oncologist.  I was two weeks into chemo by the earliest surgery date they could give me--and I wasn't having any recon or recon prep--just a bilat mx. So sorry this is happening Ann.  You have been a real advocate for yourself and tireless in pursuing your path.  Cathy
